description.narrative:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This assessment forms the basis for a new three-year agreement between Oxfam GB and Sida to support Oxfam GB’s humanitarian programme from 1 April 2018 to 31 March 2021, where additional contributions will be added to the agreement, subject to funds availability, governmental appropriations and Sida needs assessments.
In 2018, more than 135 million people will be in need of humanitarian assistance globally to a cost of 22.5 billion dollar, according to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). Sweden's humanitarian assistance is needs-based and Sida each year undertakes a humanitarian allocation process in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected.
A number of the identified global needs for 2018 are found in protracted and forgotten crises, and Sida believes that Oxfam GB is well positioned to respond to these needs as the organization is also working with long-term development cooperation. Moreover, Oxfam GB has extensive knowledge of the local context in all proposed projects and capacity building of local actors is central to Oxfam GB's humanitarian work. In 2018-2021, it is therefore suggested that Oxfam GB receives support for emergency lifesaving activities as well as funding for longer-term activities aimed at strengthening societies’ resilience to crises and disasters.
Oxfam GB has in previous collaborations with Sida demonstrated that the organisation is a professional and efficient humanitarian actor, most recently in the agreements during 2011-2013 and 2014-2017. In 2016 alone, Oxfam GB managed to reach 1.2 million people with humanitarian support in the sector of WASH, 94,000 people with food security and livelihood interventions and 106,000 people with protection assistance in conflict-affected settings. In line with this, Sida believes that Oxfam GB has an added value when it comes to activities of food security and livelihoods, WASH and protection. Moreover, Sida assesses that Oxfam GB's planned projects are relevant in accordance with Sida’s Humanitarian Crisis Analyses (HCA) that form the basis for the allocation of a majority of the humanitarian funds for 2018 and contribute to the achievement of the goals of the Strategy for Sweden’s humanitarian aid provided through the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) 2017–2020. Sida therefore proposes to support Oxfam GB's humanitarian projects to a cost of 104 MSEK.
In 2018-2021, Oxfam GB plans to reach over 280,000 people in Algeria, the Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Iraq and Chad. The contribution will consist of four components focusing on emergency life-saving activities; multi-year resilience building projects; the possibility to respond to sudden onset or deteriorating humanitarian emergencies during the year through the Rapid Response Mechanism; as well as support to method development of cash-based programming.
Two 1-year projects are proposed to be funded with a total of 5 MSEK with the following breakdown:
Democratic Republic of Congo: 1 MSEK In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Oxfam will provide support to an INGO forum with 100 NGO members with the aim of increasing the effectiveness of humanitarian interventions through improved coordination.
Iraq: 4 MSEK In Iraq, Sida will support a project focusing on first line emergency response. The projects will target 9,600 people and include activities of food distribution as well as distribution of non-food items and hygiene materials.
Five 3-year projects are proposed to be funded with a total of 28 MSEK for 2018, 19 MSEK for 2019 and 16 MSEK for 2019 with the following breakdown:
Algeria: 15 MSEK (5+5+5 MSEK) In Algeria, 126 600 Sahrawi refugees will be supported in a project focusing on improving dietary diversity and strengthening of small-scale agriculture with the aim of increasing food security in the refugee camps. To reach the planned goals of the project, Oxfam will distribute fresh vegetables and flour, conduct trainings and awareness sessions on agricultural production and introduce drought-resistant crops.
Central African Republic: 18 MSEK (10+5+3 MSEK) In the Central African Republic, Oxfam will target 17,500 people with food, protection and WASH activities, together with resilience building through recovery of productive assets and strengthening of communities’ conflict management capabilities. The proposed activities include distribution of agricultural kits, awareness-raising on food diversification, protection and gender themes as well as strengthening of community protection committees.
Chad: 18 MSEK (10+5+3 MSEK) The project in Chad will target 49,087 people in a project aiming to improve access to basic social services, protection, and the restoration of livelihoods. The project activities include borehole drilling, trainings of water management committees, latrine construction and hygiene promotion. The project will also highlight issues of protection and gender-based violence through awareness raising, establishment of protection committees, mapping of care services for victims of abuses and violations and awareness raising sessions on protection issues.
Iraq: 12 MSEK (3+4+5 MSEK) In Iraq, Sida will support a project focusing on capacity building of local humanitarian leadership with the aim of strengthening the local humanitarian response capacity. The projects will target local humanitarian actors as well as a number of local NGOs.
Moreover, it is further proposed that Sida contributes with 25 million within the Rapid Response Mechanism, RRM, to enable Oxfam GB to respond to sudden onset or deteriorating humanitarian emergencies throughout the year.
Moreover, in addition to funding provided directly to Oxfam GB, Sida will also support the Cash Learning Partnership (CaLP) in a 3-year intervention with a total funding of 9 MSEK (4+3+2 MSEK). CaLP is a network based on learning, knowledge sharing, networking and coordination around the appropriate and timely use of cash transfer programming (CTP) in humanitarian response. CaLP does not deliver cash transfer programmes directly. The vision of CaLP is that humanitarian assistance creates the greatest value, choice and dignity for people in crisis. CaLP has six Global Objectives: 1. Ensure sufficient funding is available for cash transfer programming. 2. Ensure cash is systematically considered as an option. 3. Build sufficient capacity for cash transfer programming. 4. Strengthen coordination. 5. Ensure the effectiveness and quality of cash transfer programming. 6. Build evidence and invest in innovation. The work of CaLP’s secretariat is summarised in four strategic objectives: 1. Provide specialist capacity building services and advice. 2. Make the evidence base easily accessible, improve it and apply it through standards and tools. 3. Provide specialist support to coordinating bodies. 4. Ensure influential policy processes promote CTP and the six Global Objectives.
The support to CaLP is in line with Strategy for Sweden’s humanitarian aid provided through the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) 2017–2020 as well as Sida’s commitments to cash in the World Humanitarian Summit (WHS) and in the Grand Bargain. Sida assesses that CaLP is a key organisation to work with to reach the aims of the humanitarian strategy and that the collaboration with CaLP will benefit not only Sida but the humanitarian sector as a whole. As CaLP is not a legal body and is hosted by the Humanitarian Department of Oxfam House, it is decided to include the support to CaLP in this appraisal and in the agreement between Oxfam GB and Sida.
Finally, in addition to the funding of Oxfam GB's humanitarian projects, Oxfam GB will also receive 2 MSEK in programme management costs. This is further elaborated in the budget section in this appraisal.
For a detailed overview of the p

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Detta beslut avser stöd till Oxfam GB för humanitära projekt genom ett nytt avtal mellan Sida och Oxfam GB för perioden april 2018 – juni 2021.
Under 2018 kommer fler än 135 miljoner människor vara i behov av humanitärt bistånd världen över till en kostnad av 22,5 miljarder dollar enligt United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). Sveriges humanitära bistånd är behovsbaserat och Sida genomför i enlighet med detta årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess, vari samtliga humanitära kriser analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven och där de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer att svara upp mot identifierade behov utväljs.
Ett flertal av de identifierade globala behoven för 2018 återfinns i utdragna och bortglömda kriser och Sida bedömer att Oxfam GB är väl positionerad att svara upp mot dessa behov i kraft av att organisationen även arbetar med långsiktigt utvecklingssamarbete, har god kännedom om den lokala kontexten i samtliga föreslagna projekt samt genom att kapacitetsstärkande av lokala aktörer är centralt i Oxfam GB’s humanitära arbete. År 2018–2021 föreslås därför att Oxfam GB, utöver stöd för akut livräddande aktiviteter, även erhåller finansiering för mer långsiktiga aktiviteter i syfte att stärka samhällens motståndskraft mot kriser och katastrofer.
Oxfam GB har under tidigare samarbeten med Sida, senast genom stöd under avtalsperioden 2011–2013 samt 2014–2017, påvisat att organisationen är en effektiv humanitär aktör. Enbart under 2016 lyckades Oxfam GB nå 1,2 miljoner människor med stöd inom vatten, sanitet och hygien, 94 000 människor med tryggad livsmedelsförsörjning och förbättrade försörjningsmöjligheter samt bidra med stärkt skydd för 106 000 människor i konfliktdrabbade miljöer. Sida bedömer i linje med detta att Oxfam GB framförallt har ett mervärde vad gäller aktiviteter inom tryggad livsmedelsförsörjning, genom matdistribution och kontantbaserat stöd; försörjningsmöjligheter, bland annat genom stöd till återhämtning inom boskapsskötsel och jordbruk; vatten, sanitet och hygien, både genom akut livräddande aktiviteter och långsiktiga aktiviteter i syfte att stärka vattensystem; samt skydd, såväl genom integrering av skydd i exempelvis matdistribution som specifika skyddsaktiviteter i syfte att exempelvis öka medvetenheten om könsbaserat våld. Oxfam arbetar även aktivt med påverkansarbete kring internationell humanitär rätt och de humanitära principerna.
År 2018-2021 planerar Oxfam GB att nå över 280 000 personer i Algeriet, Centralafrikanska republiken, Demokratiska republiken Kongo, Irak och Tchad. Insatsen kommer bestå av fyra komponenter med fokus på akut livräddande aktiviteter; projekt i syfte att stärka samhällens motståndskraft mot kriser och katastrofer; möjlighet att snabbt svara upp mot hastigt uppkomna behov i nya kriser eller akuta försämringar av pågående kriser inom ramen för snabbinsatsmekanismen RRM; samt stärkt effektivitet i det humanitära systemet genom metodstöd som syftar till att öka kunskapen om kontantbaserat stöd.
Sida bedömer att Oxfam GB’s planerade projekt svarar mot aktuella humanitära behov i enlighet med Sidas geografiska analys och stöd till den föreslagna insatsen bedöms som relevant för att uppnå målen i Strategi för Sveriges humanitära bistånd genom Styrelsen för internationellt utvecklingssamarbete (Sida) 2017–2020. Sida föreslår därför att stödja Oxfam GB’s humanitära projekt till en kostnad av 104 MSEK i enlighet med följande:
Landprojekt
Två 1-åriga projekt föreslås finansieras med totalt 5 MSEK med följande fördelning:
Demokratiska republiken Kongo: 1 MSEK I Demokratiska republiken Kongo planerar Oxfam GB att stödja ett INGO-forum med 100 icke-statliga medlemsorganisationer i syfte att öka effektiviteten av humanitärt bistånd genom stärkt samordning.
Irak: 4 MSEK I Irak föreslås att Sida stödjer ett projekt som riktar sig till 9 600 personer med livräddande aktiviteter inom bland annat vatten, sanitet och hygien samt tryggad livsmedelsförsörjning genom exempelvis distribution av hygienartiklar, mat och andra basala förnödenheter.
Fem 3-åriga projekt föreslås finansieras med totalt 28 MSEK för 2018, 19 MSEK för 2019 samt 16 MSEK för 2020 med följande fördelning:
Algeriet: 15 MSEK (5+5+5 MSEK) I Algeriet planerar Oxfam GB att stödja 126 600 västsahariska flyktingar i ett projekt som fokuserar på tryggad livsmedelsförsörjning och stärkt motståndskraft mot framtida kriser och katastrofer, genom bland annat distribution av färska grönsaker och introduktion av klimatanpassade grödor.
Centralafrikanska republiken: 18 MSEK (10+5+3 MSEK) I Centralafrikanska republiken planerar Oxfam GB att nå 17 500 personer från de mest utsatta konfliktdrabbade grupperna i två projekt med aktiviteter inom tryggad livsmedelsförsörjning, skydd samt vatten, sanitet och hygien, genom exempelvis distribution av jordbruksredskap, utbildning i syfte att stärka kunskapen om diversifierad kosthållning samt skyddsaktiviteter, bland annat bestående av kapacitetsstärkning av skyddskommittéer.
Tchad: 18 MSEK (10+5+3 MSEK) I Tchad planerar Oxfam GB att stödja 49 087 människor, inklusive internflyktingar och personer från värdsamhällen, med aktiviteter inom skydd samt vatten, sanitet och hygien. Projektverksamheten innefattar bland annat brunnsborrning, utbildning inom vatten, sanitet och hygien samt konstruktion av latriner. Projektet kommer även inkludera inrättande av skyddskommittéer samt aktiviteter som syftar till att öka medvetenheten om könsbaserat våld.
Irak: 12 MSEK (3+4+5 MSEK) I Irak förslås stöd till ett kapacitetsstärkande projekt av lokala humanitära organisationer samt ett antal lokala civilsamhällsorganisationer i syfte att förbättra den lokala responskapaciteten och därmed stärka lokalsamhällets motståndskraft mot framtida kriser och katastrofer.
Rapid Response Mechanism
Vidare föreslås att Sida bidrar med 25 MSEK inom ramen för snabbinsatsmekanismen RRM för att möjliggöra för Oxfam GB att snabbt svara upp mot hastigt uppkomna behov i nya kriser eller akuta försämringar av pågående kriser.
Metodstöd
Ett metodprojekt till Cash Learning Partnership (CaLP) föreslås finansieras med totalt 4 MSEK för 2018, 3 MSEK för 2019 samt 2 MSEK för 2019:
CaLP är ett nätverk som arbetar med lärande, kunskapsdelning, nätverkande och koordination gällande kontantbaserat stöd. Mot bakgrund av att Sida i samband med World Humanitarian Summit och Grand Bargain åtagit sig att stärka arbetet med kontantbaserat stöd, rekommenderas i denna beredning att inkludera stöd till CaLP. Detta stöd ingår i beredningen av Oxfam GB eftersom CaLP inte är en egen juridisk person utan återfinns inom Humanitarian Department of Oxfam House.
Sida föreslår även att finansiera Oxfam GB’s programhanteringskostnader till en total kostnad av 2 MSEK för 2018. Programhanteringskostnaderna täcker en programkoordinator (100%), en finansiell funktion (75%), en programansvarig (100%), tekniskt rådgivande stöd (inom exempelvis tryggad livsmedelsförsörjning och skydd) samt fältuppföljning och externa revisionskostnader. Sida bedömer att programhanteringskostnaderna är nödvändiga för att säkra kvaliteten på hanteringen av Sida-medlen eftersom delar av de administrativa kostnaderna på 7% vidarebefordras till andra delar av Oxfams federation och därmed inte kommer Oxfam GB till del.
För detaljerad överblick och fördelning av Sidas stöd hänvisas till avtalets bilaga VII (Budget summary).
Även om Sida bedömer att Oxfam GB har god kapacitet att implementera humanitära projekt har Sida under tidigare samarbeten noterat vissa svagheter vad gäller intern styrning och kontroll, framförallt vad gäller revision, vidareförmedling samt finansiell rapportering. Sida kommer därför under 2018 att följa hur väl Oxfam GB åtgärdar brister inom dessa områden.
Med anledning av de uppmärksammade fallen där Oxfam GB’s personal varit inblandade i sexuellt utnyttjande och andra

Fewer women, men and children will die or suffer from a loss of dignity through insecurity and deprivation by reducing the impact of natural disasters and conflict and strengthening the resilience of communities and local partners.

description.narrative: During the first year of the agreement period, Oxfam was able to reach over 633,000 beneficiaries with humanitarian assistance through 16 projects in 11 countries, such as in the Central African Republic, Chad, Colombia, Iraq and Syria, particularly with activities in the sectors of WASH, food and protection. Below follow some notable results from the first year of the agreement: - Through the supply of water pumps and rehabilitation of wells and water points, 129,789 people displaced by conflict in Dar’a, Syria, have got access to adequate and safe water. - Through WASH support to flood affected people in Batangafo, Central African Republic, 35,784 people got access to clean water and sanitation services through water trucking and construction/rehabilitation of sanitation facilities. - In Chad, 38,133 IDPs, returnees and host communities impacted by violence by Boko Haram received WASH, food and protection support. Through the construction of boreholes, strengthening of protection committees and, unconditional cash transfers, the beneficiaries’ access to food and water was improved and protection risk cases resolved. In addition, throughout the previous agreement period, 2014-2018, Oxfam reached over 3 500 000 beneficiaries with humanitarian assistance through 52 projects in 29 countries, mainly with activities in the sectors of WASH, food and protection. Below follow some notable results: - 61,692 people in Kasai in DRC reached with WASH support resulting in increased access to water and improved water and sanitation practices. - 125,800 Sahrawi refugees in Algeria reached with food security and livelihood support which contributed to reduce food insecurity and improve dietary diversity. - 153,414 beneficiaries reached with WASH support resulting in increased access to appropriate WASH facilities through the rehabilitation of water supply schemes in Rural Damascus in Syria. - 75,262 individuals in North and South Kivu in DRC reached with protection support which contributed to increase awareness around various protection issues and that the beneficiaries became better in identifying react, address and enhance protection concerns. - 86,460 people reached with life-saving WASH support which resulted in increased access to safe water for Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This assessment forms the basis for a new three-year agreement between Oxfam GB and Sida to support Oxfam GB’s humanitarian programme from 1 April 2018 to 31 March 2021, where additional contributions will be added to the agreement, subject to funds availability, governmental appropriations and Sida needs assessments.
In 2018, more than 135 million people will be in need of humanitarian assistance globally to a cost of 22.5 billion dollar, according to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). Sweden's humanitarian assistance is needs-based and Sida each year undertakes a humanitarian allocation process in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected.
A number of the identified global needs for 2018 are found in protracted and forgotten crises, and Sida believes that Oxfam GB is well positioned to respond to these needs as the organization is also working with long-term development cooperation. Moreover, Oxfam GB has extensive knowledge of the local context in all proposed projects and capacity building of local actors is central to Oxfam GB's humanitarian work. In 2018-2021, it is therefore suggested that Oxfam GB receives support for emergency lifesaving activities as well as funding for longer-term activities aimed at strengthening societies’ resilience to crises and disasters.
Oxfam GB has in previous collaborations with Sida demonstrated that the organisation is a professional and efficient humanitarian actor, most recently in the agreements during 2011-2013 and 2014-2017. In 2016 alone, Oxfam GB managed to reach 1.2 million people with humanitarian support in the sector of WASH, 94,000 people with food security and livelihood interventions and 106,000 people with protection assistance in conflict-affected settings. In line with this, Sida believes that Oxfam GB has an added value when it comes to activities of food security and livelihoods, WASH and protection. Moreover, Sida assesses that Oxfam GB's planned projects are relevant in accordance with Sida’s Humanitarian Crisis Analyses (HCA) that form the basis for the allocation of a majority of the humanitarian funds for 2018 and contribute to the achievement of the goals of the Strategy for Sweden’s humanitarian aid provided through the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) 2017–2020. Sida therefore proposes to support Oxfam GB's humanitarian projects to a cost of 104 MSEK.
In 2018-2021, Oxfam GB plans to reach over 280,000 people in Algeria, the Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Iraq and Chad. The contribution will consist of four components focusing on emergency life-saving activities; multi-year resilience building projects; the possibility to respond to sudden onset or deteriorating humanitarian emergencies during the year through the Rapid Response Mechanism; as well as support to method development of cash-based programming.
Two 1-year projects are proposed to be funded with a total of 5 MSEK with the following breakdown:
Democratic Republic of Congo: 1 MSEK In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Oxfam will provide support to an INGO forum with 100 NGO members with the aim of increasing the effectiveness of humanitarian interventions through improved coordination.
Iraq: 4 MSEK In Iraq, Sida will support a project focusing on first line emergency response. The projects will target 9,600 people and include activities of food distribution as well as distribution of non-food items and hygiene materials.
Five 3-year projects are proposed to be funded with a total of 28 MSEK for 2018, 19 MSEK for 2019 and 16 MSEK for 2019 with the following breakdown:
Algeria: 15 MSEK (5+5+5 MSEK) In Algeria, 126 600 Sahrawi refugees will be supported in a project focusing on improving dietary diversity and strengthening of small-scale agriculture with the aim of increasing food security in the refugee camps. To reach the planned goals of the project, Oxfam will distribute fresh vegetables and flour, conduct trainings and awareness sessions on agricultural production and introduce drought-resistant crops.
Central African Republic: 18 MSEK (10+5+3 MSEK) In the Central African Republic, Oxfam will target 17,500 people with food, protection and WASH activities, together with resilience building through recovery of productive assets and strengthening of communities’ conflict management capabilities. The proposed activities include distribution of agricultural kits, awareness-raising on food diversification, protection and gender themes as well as strengthening of community protection committees.
Chad: 18 MSEK (10+5+3 MSEK) The project in Chad will target 49,087 people in a project aiming to improve access to basic social services, protection, and the restoration of livelihoods. The project activities include borehole drilling, trainings of water management committees, latrine construction and hygiene promotion. The project will also highlight issues of protection and gender-based violence through awareness raising, establishment of protection committees, mapping of care services for victims of abuses and violations and awareness raising sessions on protection issues.
Iraq: 12 MSEK (3+4+5 MSEK) In Iraq, Sida will support a project focusing on capacity building of local humanitarian leadership with the aim of strengthening the local humanitarian response capacity. The projects will target local humanitarian actors as well as a number of local NGOs.
Moreover, it is further proposed that Sida contributes with 25 million within the Rapid Response Mechanism, RRM, to enable Oxfam GB to respond to sudden onset or deteriorating humanitarian emergencies throughout the year.
Moreover, in addition to funding provided directly to Oxfam GB, Sida will also support the Cash Learning Partnership (CaLP) in a 3-year intervention with a total funding of 9 MSEK (4+3+2 MSEK). CaLP is a network based on learning, knowledge sharing, networking and coordination around the appropriate and timely use of cash transfer programming (CTP) in humanitarian response. CaLP does not deliver cash transfer programmes directly. The vision of CaLP is that humanitarian assistance creates the greatest value, choice and dignity for people in crisis. CaLP has six Global Objectives: 1. Ensure sufficient funding is available for cash transfer programming. 2. Ensure cash is systematically considered as an option. 3. Build sufficient capacity for cash transfer programming. 4. Strengthen coordination. 5. Ensure the effectiveness and quality of cash transfer programming. 6. Build evidence and invest in innovation. The work of CaLP’s secretariat is summarised in four strategic objectives: 1. Provide specialist capacity building services and advice. 2. Make the evidence base easily accessible, improve it and apply it through standards and tools. 3. Provide specialist support to coordinating bodies. 4. Ensure influential policy processes promote CTP and the six Global Objectives.
The support to CaLP is in line with Strategy for Sweden’s humanitarian aid provided through the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) 2017–2020 as well as Sida’s commitments to cash in the World Humanitarian Summit (WHS) and in the Grand Bargain. Sida assesses that CaLP is a key organisation to work with to reach the aims of the humanitarian strategy and that the collaboration with CaLP will benefit not only Sida but the humanitarian sector as a whole. As CaLP is not a legal body and is hosted by the Humanitarian Department of Oxfam House, it is decided to include the support to CaLP in this appraisal and in the agreement between Oxfam GB and Sida.
Finally, in addition to the funding of Oxfam GB's humanitarian projects, Oxfam GB will also receive 2 MSEK in programme management costs. This is further elaborated in the budget section in this appraisal.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Detta beslut avser stöd till Oxfam GB för humanitära projekt genom ett nytt avtal mellan Sida och Oxfam GB för perioden april 2018 – juni 2021.
Under 2018 kommer fler än 135 miljoner människor vara i behov av humanitärt bistånd världen över till en kostnad av 22,5 miljarder dollar enligt United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). Sveriges humanitära bistånd är behovsbaserat och Sida genomför i enlighet med detta årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess, vari samtliga humanitära kriser analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven och där de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer att svara upp mot identifierade behov utväljs.
Ett flertal av de identifierade globala behoven för 2018 återfinns i utdragna och bortglömda kriser och Sida bedömer att Oxfam GB är väl positionerad att svara upp mot dessa behov i kraft av att organisationen även arbetar med långsiktigt utvecklingssamarbete, har god kännedom om den lokala kontexten i samtliga föreslagna projekt samt genom att kapacitetsstärkande av lokala aktörer är centralt i Oxfam GB’s humanitära arbete. Through the construction of boreholes, strengthening of protection committees and, unconditional cash transfers, the beneficiaries’ access to food and water was improved and protection risk cases resolved. In addition, throughout the previous agreement period, 2014-2018, Oxfam reached over 3 500 000 beneficiaries with humanitarian assistance through 52 projects in 29 countries, mainly with activities in the sectors of WASH, food and protection. Below follow some notable results: - 61,692 people in Kasai in DRC reached with WASH support resulting in increased access to water and improved water and sanitation practices. - 125,800 Sahrawi refugees in Algeria reached with food security and livelihood support which contributed to reduce food insecurity and improve dietary diversity. - 153,414 beneficiaries reached with WASH support resulting in increased access to appropriate WASH facilities through the rehabilitation of water supply schemes in Rural Damascus in Syria. - 75,262 individuals in North and South Kivu in DRC reached with protection support which contributed to increase awareness around various protection issues and that the beneficiaries became better in identifying react, address and enhance protection concerns. - 86,460 people reached with life-saving WASH support which resulted in increased access to safe water for Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Musharaka: Youth-led community development in the Sahrawi refugee camps

description.narrative:
This project will apply a community driven development approach where the community in the five Sahrawi refugee camps will form taskforces, with at least 50 % youth and 50 % female representation, that will consult with the community, authorities and other stakeholders to define needs and then design projects that address the community needs. Approximately 15 MSEK will be allocated for these community projects. The intention with the approach is to create a high degree ownership, help address some of the social service needs in the camps and provide an avenue for young people to demonstrate their contribution to community development. A comprehensive training and workshop package will also be provided to the taskforces to enable the implementation of the project.
The project will be implemented by Oxfam Solidarité. Oxfam has been working on the Sahrawi refugee situation since 1975 and is therefore one of the oldest humanitarian actors in the camps and has over time gained legitimacy and respect among the community and authorities.

Detta projekt kommer att tillämpa en så kallad "community driven development approach" där befolkningen i de fem västsahariska flyktinglägren kommer att bilda kommittéer (där minst 50 % är ungdomar och minst 50 % är kvinnor) som kommer att samråda med befolkningen i lägren, myndigheter och andra intressenter för att definiera behov och sedan utforma projekt som möter samhällets behov. Ungefär 15 miljoner kronor kommer att tilldelas dessa sub-projekt och syftet med tillvägagångssättet är att skapa en hög grad av lokalt ägarskap, att åtgärda en del av behoven för förbättrade samhällstjänster i lägren samt ge ungdomar en plattform för att visa att de kan bidra till samhällsutvecklingen. Ett antal utbildningar och workshops för kommittérna kommer även att organiseras som en del av projektet.
Projektet kommer att genomföras av Oxfam Solidarité. Oxfam har arbetat med situationen med västsahariska flyktingar sedan 1975 och är således en av de äldsta humanitära aktörerna i lägren och har med tiden skaffat sig legitimitet och respekt hos flyktingarna och myndigheterna.

Main objective: to improve the role of youth in community development in the Sahrawi refugee camps Specific objective: Strengthening the capacities and self-confidence of youth, and their recognition as active participants in community development, by the authorities and other stakeholders Result 1: The five taskforces, selected through a participative and inclusive process, are functional, and are aware of their responsibility towards the community. Result 2: Community taskforces have completed a cycle of training and improved their technical skills Result 3: Youth, as an important part of the taskforces, have developed and successfully implemented inclusive and sustainable projects that respond to the needs of the community Result 4: Local authorities and taskforces have developed a relationship of trust. Since the community projects under result 3 will be designed during the implementation the results framework will be updated by Oxfam when their focus have been agreed. The updated results framework will be submitted to Sida for approval as stipulated in the agreement.

tag.narrative: 16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

16.a - Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.

description.narrative: Support to Sahrawi refugees in Tindouf, Algeria. Animal protein (mackerel) to meet the nutritional needs. Also distribution of clothing/shoes.

Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till avtal med Praktisk Solidaritet (PS) om bidrag till humanitära insatser 2011-2016. Beslutet tas i enlighet med Sidas insatshanteringsregel paragraf 3.11.3 och avser förlängd aktivitetsperiod och medelstillägg om totalt 7 483 015 SEK.
Sida har sedan 1998 gett finansiellt stöd till PS för deras verksamhet i flyktingläger belägna i sydvästra Algeriet. Sida:s stöd har till en början fokuserat på distribution av kläder, vilket övergick till att även inkludera distribution av tonfisk. Under 2009 utförde ett lokalt utvärderingsteam i flyktingläger, hädanefter refererade som "monitoras", en utvärdering av matdistributionen. Denna utvärdering visade på att mottagarna inte var nöjda med tonfisk, och PS bytte då fisk till makrill istället, vilka har haft ett positivt mottagande av mottagarna.
PS har sedan 2011 även samarbetat med Comitato Internazionale per lo Sviluppo dei Popoli (CISP) vad gäller ett projekt som producerar ett traditionellt klädesplagg för kvinnor, även kallat "melfa". Detta var ett pilotprojekt vilket PS tillsammans med CISP åtog sig, där insatsens mål är att skapa större hållbarhet och självständighet för de kvinnor som deltar i projektet.
Målgruppen för denna insats är totalt 125 000 västsahariska flyktingar, vilka alla nu befinner sig i utdragna flyktingläger belägna i Sydvästra Algeriet. Behoven i dessa flyktingläger är stora samt att det finns ett beroende hos flyktingarna av hjälporganisationer i tillgång till matstöd. PS planerar att dela ut matstöd till samtliga flyktingar (enligt denna räkning), samt att distribuera kläder till samtliga flyktingar. PS genom sina partnerorganisationer avser med denna insats att bidra till en mer balanserad diet vilket riktar mot den felnäring som finns inom flyktinglägren, samt att upprätthålla mänsklig värdighet genom melfaproduktion och utdelning av kläder.
PS samarbetar med både Sahariska Röda Halvmånen (SRH) och Algeriska Röda Halvmånen (ARH) för att möjliggöra distribuering av konserverad makrill och kläder. PS samarbetar även med CISP i både projektet vad gäller produktion av melfa, men även i arbetet med uppföljning och utvärdering av PS insatser relaterat till utdelning av konserverad makrill och kläder.
Projektet avser att, för de Västsahariska flyktingarna i sydvästra Algeriet minska förekomsten av undernäring och felnäring samt garantera tillgången till en miniminivå av kläder och skor. Insatsen inbegriper: upphandling och distribution av 312 ton konserverad makrill, insamling och distribution av 117 ton kläder och skor samt ett pilotprojekt för framställning (färgning) av Melfor, det traditionella klädesplagg för västsahariska kvinnor. För Melfa projektet hade PS outnyttjade medel kvar från tidigare beslut, och inkom med en förfrågan om överföring av medel för detta delprojekt, samt förlängning av implementeringsperiod. PS hade ytterligare oanvända medel från tidigare beslut, vilka de bad om att få föra över till den nya aktivitetsperioden. Totalbudget för projektet är 7 820 000 SEK, varav detta beslut innefattar 7 483 015 SEK.
Sida har fört en diskussion med PS angående deras beräkning av mottagare av stödet. PS beräkning är inte enligt WFP:s beräkning, som avser att dela ut 90 000 ransoner av basmatkorg. PS menar att de följer WFP:s utdelningslogik och beräkning, och ska i framtiden förtydliga detta i sina ansökningar samt rapporteringar. Sida kommer att fortsatt diskutera denna fråga med PS.
Sida har sedan 2013 fört en dialog med PS angående fortsatt finansiering av denna insats på det humanitära allokeringsanslaget. Sida har bedömt att PS har jobbat för att förbättra sina interna styrning och kontroll. Sida identifierar PS som en väletablerad aktör i den västsahariska flyktingsituationen. Sedan 2013 jobbar Sida:s humanitära enhet med strategiska partnerorganisationer vilka har en omfattande humanitär kompetens och närvaro i flera humanitära kontexter. PS arbetar endast med humanitära insatser i de algeriska flyktinglägren och är därmed inte strategisk partnerorganisation till Sida. Sida har identifierat flera strategiska partnerorganisationer vilka implementerar insatser i de Algeriska flyktinglägren som huserar de västsahariska flyktinglägren. Strategiska partnerorganisationer har bedömts av Sida som professionella aktörer med stor kapacitet och kompetens att svara på stora humanitär behov. Sida kommer att fortsätta dialogen under 2015 med PS angående eventuellt fortsatt stöd eller utfasning och se över möjligheten med fortsatt humanitärt stöd till insatser vad gäller västsahariska flyktingar genom andra strategiska partnerorganisationer i första hand.

Det övergripande målet med insatsen är minskad förekomst av undernäring och garanterad minimistandard av kläder och skor bland de västsahariska flyktingarna som bor i flyktingläger i sydvästra Algeriet.

description.narrative: Praktisk Solidaritet (PS) har, som ett komplement till WFP:s matdistribution, distribueratkonserverad makrill för att tillgodose behovet av animaliskt protein i kosten hos devästsahariska flyktingarna. Under avtalsperioden år 2011-2017 har 2 222 ton makrilldistribuerats till 125 000 västsahariska flyktingar. PS har dessutom samlat in kläder (i första hand från Sverige) och distribuerat sammanlagt 945 ton kläder till de 125 000 flyktingarna samt stöttat ett inkomstgenererande projektbestående av produktion av melfor, ett traditionellt klädesplagg för västsahariska kvinnor.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Humanitarian support to UNHCR in UN Consolidated and Emergency Appeals
Humanitärt stöd till UNHCRs aktiviteter i FNs samlade appeller

description.narrative:
Sida has assessed the UN High Commissioner for Refugees as a relevant and strategic humanitarian partner with good implementation capacity. Sida’s Central Organisational Assessment of UNHCR (2015) concludes that the organisation’s systems for internal control are adequate according and in line with Sida contribution regulations.
Sida provides support, in addition to the MFA's annual core contribution, based on the UN Consolidated Appeals (HRP) and UNHCRs Global Appeal, Supplementary Budget Appeals and UNHCR Regional Response Plans (RRRP). Sida allocates funding to UNHCR on a country / regional level and support is unearmarked at this level. During the year Sida assesses UNHCR's Supplementary Appeals for possible additional funding through supplementary decisions.
With its mandate, to protect refugees, forcibly displaced communities and stateless people, and assist in their voluntary repatriation, local integration or resettlement to a third country, UNHCR is alongside ICRC Sida’s key protection partner. In addition to its operational role in the protection of refugees, UNHCR has a normative role in monitoring and interpreting the Refugee Convention. UNHCR is the lead Agency in Refugee operations within the humanitarian system with responsibility to coordinate UN agencies and NGOs response in refugee crisis. This includes coordination of several regional refugee appeals such as Syria, Horn of Africa, Nigeria, South Sudan, Yemen, CAR, Burundi and Europe.
UNHCR coordinates its response under OCHA in emergency within countries (internally displaced people). UNHCR is responsible for leading and coordinating the Protection Cluster, the clusters of Camp Coordination and Camp Management, as well as the Emergency Shelter cluster. UNHCR is thereby contributing strategically to the humanitarian system, at global, regional and country level.
Through this support Sida contributes humanitarian funding to UNHCR in order to assist refugees and internally displaced people in armed conflict, providing legal protection from persecution and violence, emergency shelter (tents, semi-permanent structures, rent for temporary accommodation) and basic necessities (such as food, water, hygiene and primary health care, etc), as well as opportunities for durable solutions, when the situation so allows.
The country allocations for 2019 includes a total of 250 MSEK, including 30 MSEK to the global COVID-19 response plan.
To facilitate rapid humanitarian planning and response, disbursement the main part of the amount is made at the beginning of the year after signing of the Agreement and upon disbursement request from UNHCR. Funds are utilized within a short timeframe after disbursement and UNHCR has a general utilization rate of 98% of the annual contributions. It is Sida's experience that funds available for activities at the country level rarely reaches or exceeds UNHCR's total funding needs. The funding level for UNHCR is generally about 50% of the annual budget. In the exceptional case that UNHCR has not utilized the entire Sida contribution by the end of the year, Sida has been duly informed and the balance have been regulated in accordance with the agreement. The proposed payment plan is thus in line with Sida's rule for contribution management § 2.8.4, which stipulates that payment will be made in close connection with the time when the funds will be used, and as the funding needs arise.

Denna insats rör avtal med "The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)" från 2014, om bidrag till humanitära insatser.
Med sitt mandat att skydda flyktingar, tvångsfördrivna och statslösa, se till dessas möjlighet att återvända, vidarebosättas eller integreras i sina värdsamhällen, så är UNHCR, tillsammans med ICRC, Sidas viktigaste partner inom skyddsområdet. Utöver sin operativa roll i skyddet av flyktingar (juridisk hjälp, utfärda identitetshandlingar, asylrätt, etc) har UNHCR en normativ roll i övervakning och tolkning av flyktingkonventionen. UNHCR är inom humanitära systemet huvudaktören i alla flyktingkriser, med övergripande koordineringsansvar av FN- och civilsamhällsorganisationers humanitära arbete samt ansvarar för samarbete med nationella och lokala myndigheter. I dagsläget omfattar detta koordinering av flera regionala flyktingappeller så som Syrien, Afrikas horn, Nigeria, Sydsudan, Jemen, Centralafrikanska republiken, Burundi och i Europa.
I humanitära kriser inom ett lands gränser ansvarar "United Nations Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)" för koordineringen av den humanitära responsen, detta gäller även internflyktingkriser (Internally displaced People crisis). UNHCR ansvarar i dessa kriser för att leda och samordna arbetet i tre kluster (sektoriella koordineringsgrupper); skyddsklustret, klustret för ”Camp Coordination and Camp Management”, samt ”Emergency Shelter” klustret. UNHCR bidrar därmed till det humanitära systemet globalt, regionalt och nationellt. Utöver detta, och när situationen tillåter, arbetar UNHCR också för hållbara lösningar för flyktingar.
Genom sitt stöd till UNHCR 2020 bidrar Sida till att bistå flyktingar och internflyktingar så att dessa får skydd mot förföljelse och våld, tak över huvudet och basförnödenheter (mat, vatten, hygien, primärsjukvård, etc.) Vidare bidrar Sida till strategisk samordning inom det humanitära systemet.
Sidas finansiella bidrag till UNHCR 2020 omfattar totalt 250 MSEK, varav 30 MSEK specifikt har gått till den globala covid-19-responsplanen. Sida beslutar om detta stöd, som komplement till regeringens årliga kärnbidrag. Sidas stöd går till FNs konsoliderade humanitära appeller (Humanitarian Response Plans), UNHCRs Globala appell och UNHCRs tilläggsbudgetar (Supplementary Appeals) samt Regionala flyktingappeller (Regional Refugee Response Plans). Sida öronmärker genom avtal bidraget till UNHCR på land/region nivå men stödet är oöronmärkt inom denna nivå. Sida har under året även möjlighet att ta ställning till ytterligare stöd genom tilläggsbeslut.
Den största delen av stödet utbetalas i början av året för att UNHCR ska ges förutsättningar att planera och genomföra humanitära insatser utan fördröjning. UNHCR omsätter regelmässigt utbetalda medel i nära anslutning till utbetalning och förbrukar gåvomedel inom verksamhetsåret. Den föreslagna betalningsplanen överensstämmer således med Sidas insatshanteringsregel, avsnitt 2.8.4, där det föreskrivs att betalningen kommer att ske i nära anslutning till den tidpunkt då pengarna kommer att användas och som finansieringsbehoven uppstår. Ett avsteg från Sidas allmänna rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

Each year, Sida makes loosely earmarked contributions to UNHCR's crisis-specific Refugee Response Plans, based on Sida's model for allocation of humanitarian aid and in response to prioritized humanitarian needs through Sida's own Humanitarian Crisis Analyses. The specific objectives of the individual response plans supported may vary from one crisis to another. Nevertheless, they always align with UNHCR's overall mandate and objective to provide protection and assistance to refugees and other persons of concern to the UNHCR. According to the Mission Statement "The High Commissioner for refugees is mandated by the UN to lead and coordinate international action for the worldwide protection of refugees and the resolution of refugee problems. UNHCR’s primary purpose is to safeguard the rights and well-being of refugees." The operations are sorted under four main pillars: 1) Refugee Programme 2) Stateless Programme 3) Reintegration Projects 4) IDP Projects The individual response plans also contribute to UNHCR's Global Strategic Priorities, as set out in the UNHCR Global Appeal. These take into account the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, as well as the commitments made at the World Humanitarian Summit and under the Grand Bargain. The operational priorities of UNHCR has not changed since the last amendment and the bulk of Sida's support to UNHCR is still channeled to already planned interventions. In 2020, Sida has also provided support for UNHCR's global interventions to curb the Covid-19 pandemic and its secondary effects. The interventions supported in the end year allocation aims to meet urgent needs in two specific contexts. These represent new crises or crises with deteriorating conditions for UNHCR's people of concern. The overall objectives have not changed. Sudan (Inter-Agency Emergency Refugee Response Plan) In early November 2020, military confrontations between federal and regional forces in Ethiopia’s Tigray region, which borders both Sudan and Eritrea, led the Government to declare it in a State of Emergency. Since then, the region has been affected by incidents of armed conflict. Since early November, Eastern Sudan received large numbers of refugees through at least three border points, and there are currently no clear signs that the refugee flow is coming to an end. As of 2 December 2020 around 46,000 refugees had crossed the border to Sudan. UNHCR is planning for a scenario where up to 100,000 refugees arrive in Sudan in the coming five months. The main objectives for the operation is to support the government of Sudan in maintaining access to territory and asylum for all individuals who seek to flee to the country, through the provision of refugee protections services, including registration. UNHCR will also secure settlement of refugees in designated sites suitable for hosting large numbers of people. A key objective is to provide multi-sectoral life-saving humanitarian assistance of all new arrivals at border points and at settlement sites as well as for vulnerable host communities. Persons with specific needs and vulnerable persons should be identified and provided with targeted services. Attention will be given to COVID-19 in terms of risk communication and sensitisation, distribution of soap and hand washing facilities and face masks, establishment of isolation facilities and testing. Attention will also be given to AAP mechanisms to make sure refugees are included in planning, implementation and follow up of response activities. In short, the focus of the response will be on: - Protection and registration - Shelter, infrastructure, site planning and core relief items - WASH - Emergency health services - Logistics This is core elements in UNHCR's response in an ongoing refugee crisis. Ethiopia Ethiopia continues to suffer from the consequences of multiple crises. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the worst desert locust outbreak in 25 years, livelihoods and food security have deteriorated rapidly in 2020 and conflicts in several parts of the country have triggered mass displacements, resulting in widespread protection concerns. As a result, an unprecedented 21.3 million people are expected to need humanitarian assistance in 2021. The ongoing conflict in Tigray risks to further aggravate the humanitarian situation and humanitarian actors are planning for a scenario with an additional 1.1 million people in need of humanitarian assistance within the next two months. Sida assesses that UNHCR is well-placed to respond to the humanitarian needs of displaced populations in Ethiopia, in line with appeals, both due to its core mandate to ensure the protection of displaced populations and as a coordinator of the refugee response.

description.narrative: Sida's support to UNHCR is extensive both in terms of financials and in terms of contexts covered and the results of the intervention is hard to summarize in short. To attribute certain results specifically to Sida's contribution is almost impossible. Swedish funding, including Sida's support, amounts to approximately 3 per cent of UNHCR's income. Given the funding gap of 44 %, UNHCR manages to achieve impressive results for the 86.5 million people that the organisation targets (refugees, returnees, internally displaced, stateless and asylum seekers). UNHCR has collaborated with more than 1,000 local and international NGOs, government entities and other UN agencies to provide shelter, financial support, protection services, non-food items and much more. The organisation's advocacy work has also lead to legislative changes which improves refugees' rights. A few examples from the 16 crises Sida has supported specifically are given below (note that these are just a few examples from UNHCR's operations and not in any way a comprehensive list): Algeria - In Tindouf province, UNHCR assists Sahrawi refugees through strengthening the protection coordination mechanisms and participatory approaches that encourage community-based engagement, self-management and empowerment, in particular for youth, women and civil society organizations. UNHCR ensures that assistance reaches persons with specific needs. This includes specific assistance for some 3,000 persons with disabilities. UNHCR supports the sector to ensure a safe learning environment through provision of equipment, stationery, books and capacity-building for education staff. UNHCR provides financial incentives to more than 1,000 education staff. Burundi - Protection systems are strengthened to ensure Burundian refugees and returnees are able to enjoy their full rights, specifically with regard to safety and security, child protection, sexual and gender based violence, and community based protection. Burundian refugees, returnees and all affected persons access essential services with progressive inclusion in national health, education, social protection and other services. Approximately 21,000 Burundians were assisted to voluntary repatriate from neighboring countries. Democratic Republic of Congo - UNHCR provided shelter support; built schools, health centersand other community infrastructures; provided cash assistance; and responded to protection incidents.As part of the CCCM coordination strategy, UNHCR strengthened the capacity of site managementpersonnel and Government actors to ensure the protection of IDPs and proper site management. 61,000 IDPs benefitted from multi-purpose cash assistance, 118,000 IDPs received core relief items and 87,000 received shelter support in 2019. Ethiopia - Provided protection and assistance to more than 750,000 refugees and asylum-seekers from Eritrea, Somalia, South Sudan and Sudan, in addition to other nationalities that reside in the urban areas and to an estimated 2.5 million IDPs in Ethiopia. Refugees in Ethiopia continue to receive only about 84% of the minimum standard ration of 2,100 kcal. This has kept the global acute malnutrition rate in most camps higher than the acceptable standards. UNHCR and WFP have revised the cash transfer values for refugees currently receiving combined cash and food assistance to reflect commodity price increases in the local markets. Iraq - UNHCR worked with the Government and development actors to incorporate IDPs’ needs in development plans and support their gradual absorption into the Iraqi social welfare system. UNHCR har also supported almost 150,000 people with cash assistance, 170,000 with core relief items and 70,000 people with emergency shelter. Chad - Chad was part of the special appeal for Sahel that was launched in May 2020 to highlight the immense needs in an effort scale up shelter and education interventions and better address SGBV and otherprotection needs. In the end of 2019 primary, secondary and tertiary health care had been made available to all refugees, with comprehensive health and nutrition interventions carried out in the south of Chad. In total UNHCR targeted approximately 750,000 people with their interventions, of which more than half were refugees. Cameroon - UNHCR managed to register more than 250,000 refugees from CAR to Cameroon. Many of them were provided with emergency shelter kits, several thousand IDPs and stateless have been provided with identity documents. Mali - In coordination with the Governments of Burkina Faso, Chad, Mali, Mauritania and Niger, UNHCR initiated the development of a Sahel protection strategy, to address sexual and gender-based violence and ensure continued access to education, while providing shelter assistance in an environmentally-conscious manner in a region particularly a ected by climate change. This strategy was launched in January 2020. Myanmar/Rohingya crisis Bangladesh - In Bangladesh, UNHCR and the Government jointly completed the registration of some 855,000 Rohingya refugees, including 784,000 in 2019, providing them with identity documents — many for the first time in their lives — and establishing a basis for their right to return to Myanmar. In Myanmar itself, UNHCR advocated the rights and status of some 600,000 Rohingya who remain in Rakhine State, 140,000 of whom are internally displaced, as well as the protection of over 170,000 other IDPs throughout the country. Somalia - Against the backdrop of an ongoing state-building process, returnees and IDPs faced severe hunger, drought and ongoing insecurity. Funding shortfalls meant the majority of IDPs, and the 17,900 refugees hosted in Somalia, remained in need of urgent humanitarian assistance. Efforts continued to create an enabling environment for the reintegration of over 120,000 Somali refugee returnees who repatriated in previous years. 20,500 Somali households received cash grants. South Sudan - South Sudan remained the largest refugee displacement situation in Africa, with over 2.2 million refugees recorded. Although UNHCR’s regional intention survey highlighted that the majority ofrefugees did not have plans to return in the near future, nearly 100,000 South Sudanese refugees returned spontaneously, of which 4,560 households were assisted with core relief items. A majority of those who returned are living in IDP-like situations, in addition to an already existing internally displaced population of 1.67 million. Over 38,700 South Sudanese IDP households received core relief items. 181,000 South Sudanese children were enrolled in schools in Uganda. Syria - UNHCR and UNDP co-led the Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan in response to the Syria crisis (3RP), coordinating the work of more than 270 partners in the five main hosting countries. The Syria situation entered its ninth year with more than 5.5 million Syrian refugees hosted by neighbouring countries. UNHCR verified the return of 95,000 refugees. Inside Syria, humanitarian access to IDPs and returnees was challenging. UNHCR reached more than 1.7 million people in Syria with protection activities such as child protection and legal counselling interventions, 1.8 million people with core relief items, and 520,900 people with shelter activities. In addition, 358,000 people were assisted through the cross-border operation from Turkey. 650,000 people were reached with a total of more than 180 MUSD in cash assistance, 1.8 million people were reached with core relief items and 167,000 were reached with emergency shelter in 2019. Ukraine - UNHCR's advocacy supported egislative changes which strengthened IDPs’ voting and housing rights. Notably, an amendment to Ukraine’s electoral code facilitated their rights to vote in local elections, while greater government funding for an affordable housing programme supported access to adequate housing for IDP households. 1.4 MUSD in cas assistance was distributed and 2,600 households were provided with long-term shelter solustions. Venezuela - Within the framework of the Regional Inter-Agency Coordination Platform, UNHCR provided lifesaving assistance in border areas to new arrivals, supported access to basic goods and services, promoted peaceful coexistence with host communities, as well as access to fundamental rights, such as documentation,education and employment. 2 million people received regular stay permits or were granted asylum in neighboring countries. Close to 50,000 people received emergency shelter and 20,000 households received multi-purpose cash grants. Apart from this, UNHCR has been in the lead of the clusters for protection, camp managment and emergency shelter in several crises, strenthening the work at country level for the benefit of a wider target group than refugees, IDPs, returnees and stateless. This work is not always as effective as it could be. Sida's evaluation stated that UNHCR's leadership of clusters and overall coordination has been weak, "with concerns raised around its lack of collaboration in most study countries". Discussions with the Global Protection Cluster has informed Sida that they are aware of the challenges to improve the overall integration of protection in humanitarian response and that they are working actively to improve this. Until end of June the Covid-19 response from UNHCR provided support to the Covid-19 respons in a large number of countries. Cash asssitance of an amount of 50 MUSD have been distributed to people in need in 65 countries for example. UNHCR has also provided 85 metric tonnes of PPE equipment, 57 hospital tents, 15.5 million masks and other essential material. All in all, UNHCR's part of the Covid-19 response is assessed as highly valuable and necessary. No cases have been reported in refugee camps, which is rather exceptional. The Global Refugee Forum, held in December 2019, resulted in over 1,400 pledged accross 6 areas of focus: burden- and responsibility-sharing; education; jobs and livelihoods; energy and infrastructure; protection; and solutions. This global commitment to improving the situation for refugees, IDPs, returnees and stateless should also be viewed as a proof of UNHCR's ability to advocate for an improved policy environment for their target population in many countries around the world. On an organisational level UNHCR managed to finalized the first phase of reforms to strengthen the organization and its capacity to operate through the strengthening the field through decentralization and regionalization; strengthening risk management and operational integrity, including to address sexual exploitation and abuse and sexual harassment. A field visit to the newly established regional office in Amman showed potential for higher efficiency and the staff was very satisfied with the new ways of working, including shorter times for decision making. UNHCR states a number of challenges in their global report , including the budget gap. This has lead to painful cuts in activities, which according to the report has affected lifesaving assistance and support to meet basic needs, with cuts to food and nutritional assistance and a rise in food insecurity in places suchas Chad, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi and South Sudan. The budget shortages also hampered progress achieved by both UNHCR and partners on the prevention of risk mitigation for and response to sexual and gender-based violence in emergencies and protracted situations, with challenges including lack of funding, limited access to justice for survivors, insecurity and limited and fragmented services in certain locations. In the report to the Standing Committee, UNHCR reports on progress on all the Strategic Priorities, but it is also clear that do not reach all of their goals - in particular the operational goals. The report lacks an analysis of the reasons to why the results are not reached - or why some results have been vastly exceeded. Sida's evaluation of strategic partners, listed a number of conclusions of UNHCR's operations in a selected number of countries. In general, the results were assessed as weak, that UNHCR's work on gender equality adn targeting of PWD and minorities was weak and that they rely on partners and remote managment in hard to reach areas. Their staff and leadership capacity was found to be uneven. UNHCR has given a lengthy management response to these findings. Sida's own assessment is not as harsh as the evaluation, but Sida of course needs to take this into consideration during the upcoming appraisal.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Humanitarian support to UNHCR in UN Consolidated and Emergency Appeals
Humanitärt stöd till UNHCRs aktiviteter i FNs samlade appeller

description.narrative:
Sida has assessed the UN High Commissioner for Refugees as a relevant and strategic humanitarian partner with good implementation capacity. Sida’s Central Organisational Assessment of UNHCR (2015) concludes that the organisation’s systems for internal control are adequate according and in line with Sida contribution regulations.
Sida provides support, in addition to the MFA's annual core contribution, based on the UN Consolidated Appeals (HRP) and UNHCRs Global Appeal, Supplementary Budget Appeals and UNHCR Regional Response Plans (RRRP). Sida allocates funding to UNHCR on a country / regional level and support is unearmarked at this level. During the year Sida assesses UNHCR's Supplementary Appeals for possible additional funding through supplementary decisions.
With its mandate, to protect refugees, forcibly displaced communities and stateless people, and assist in their voluntary repatriation, local integration or resettlement to a third country, UNHCR is alongside ICRC Sida’s key protection partner. In addition to its operational role in the protection of refugees, UNHCR has a normative role in monitoring and interpreting the Refugee Convention. UNHCR is the lead Agency in Refugee operations within the humanitarian system with responsibility to coordinate UN agencies and NGOs response in refugee crisis. This includes coordination of several regional refugee appeals such as Syria, Horn of Africa, Nigeria, South Sudan, Yemen, CAR, Burundi and Europe.
UNHCR coordinates its response under OCHA in emergency within countries (internally displaced people). UNHCR is responsible for leading and coordinating the Protection Cluster, the clusters of Camp Coordination and Camp Management, as well as the Emergency Shelter cluster. UNHCR is thereby contributing strategically to the humanitarian system, at global, regional and country level.
Through this support Sida contributes humanitarian funding to UNHCR in order to assist refugees and internally displaced people in armed conflict, providing legal protection from persecution and violence, emergency shelter (tents, semi-permanent structures, rent for temporary accommodation) and basic necessities (such as food, water, hygiene and primary health care, etc), as well as opportunities for durable solutions, when the situation so allows.
The country allocations for 2019 includes a total of 250 MSEK, including 30 MSEK to the global COVID-19 response plan.
To facilitate rapid humanitarian planning and response, disbursement the main part of the amount is made at the beginning of the year after signing of the Agreement and upon disbursement request from UNHCR. Funds are utilized within a short timeframe after disbursement and UNHCR has a general utilization rate of 98% of the annual contributions. It is Sida's experience that funds available for activities at the country level rarely reaches or exceeds UNHCR's total funding needs. The funding level for UNHCR is generally about 50% of the annual budget. In the exceptional case that UNHCR has not utilized the entire Sida contribution by the end of the year, Sida has been duly informed and the balance have been regulated in accordance with the agreement. The proposed payment plan is thus in line with Sida's rule for contribution management § 2.8.4, which stipulates that payment will be made in close connection with the time when the funds will be used, and as the funding needs arise.

In short, the focus of the response will be on: - Protection and registration - Shelter, infrastructure, site planning and core relief items - WASH - Emergency health services - Logistics This is core elements in UNHCR's response in an ongoing refugee crisis. Ethiopia Ethiopia continues to suffer from the consequences of multiple crises. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the worst desert locust outbreak in 25 years, livelihoods and food security have deteriorated rapidly in 2020 and conflicts in several parts of the country have triggered mass displacements, resulting in widespread protection concerns. As a result, an unprecedented 21.3 million people are expected to need humanitarian assistance in 2021. The ongoing conflict in Tigray risks to further aggravate the humanitarian situation and humanitarian actors are planning for a scenario with an additional 1.1 million people in need of humanitarian assistance within the next two months. Sida assesses that UNHCR is well-placed to respond to the humanitarian needs of displaced populations in Ethiopia, in line with appeals, both due to its core mandate to ensure the protection of displaced populations and as a coordinator of the refugee response.
